p: Currently, micro- and macro-conidia features, the presence or absence of chlamydospores, colony appearance, and growth rates in different culture media are used to identify Fusarium species [ 14]. In consequence, the diagnosis is time-consuming and requires experts in the field. On the other hand, molecular diagnosis is a rapid, sensitive, specific and efficient alternative [ 15, 16]; including polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and sequencing techniques. In both cases, a small quantity of DNA is required during the assay. There are several PCR based methods to identify Fusarium species [ 17â€“ 22], including methods based on real-time PCR (qPCR) [ 23] moreover there are some recent approaches based on this technique for the detection of ambrosia fungi species. For example, Carrillo et al. [ 23] developed a multiplex qPCR assay using hydrolysis probes for the detection of the b-tubulin gene.
